problem: Melinda will roll two standard six-sided dice and make a two-digit number with the two numbers she rolls. For example, if she rolls a 6 and a 3, she can either form 36 or 63. What is the probability that she will be able to make an integer between 10 and 20, inclusive? Express your answer as a common fraction.
solution: She can do this if and only if at least one of the dice lands on a 1. The probability neither of the dice is a 1 is $\left(\frac{5}{6}\right) \left(\frac{5}{6}\right) = \frac{25}{36}$. So the probability at least one die is a 1 is $1-\frac{25}{36} = \boxed{\frac{11}{36}}$.
socratic_questions:
1. Can you describe the scenario and what Melinda needs to do to form a two-digit number?
2. What are the possible outcomes when rolling two standard six-sided dice?
3. How many outcomes would result in forming a two-digit number between 10 and 20 inclusive?
4. What is the probability of neither of the dice landing on a 1?
5. How can we find the probability of at least one die landing on a 1?
6. What is the probability, expressed as a common fraction, that Melinda will be able to make an integer between 10 and 20?
